description.summary: The three-headed dog guarding the gates of the underworld in Greek mythology. Offspring of Typhon and Echidna, Cerberus prevents the dead from leaving Hades rather than entering.
description.full: Cerberus is the monstrous multi-headed dog that guards the gates of the Greek underworld. Typically depicted with three heads (though some early versions describe 50 or even 100 heads), Cerberus has a serpent for a tail and a mane of writhing snakes. As the offspring of the giants Typhon and Echidna, Cerberus is sibling to other famous monsters including the Hydra and Chimera. His primary role is to prevent the dead from escaping the underworld, not to prevent entry. Cerberus features in several Greek myths, most famously when captured by Hercules as his twelfth and final labor, and when charmed to sleep by Orpheus' music. The creature symbolizes the threshold between life and death, representing an insurmountable obstacle and the finality of death.

etymology.origin: From Greek 'Kerberos' (Κέρβερος), etymology debated. Possibly from 'kēr' (death demon) + 'erebos' (darkness), or possibly means 'spotted' - a traditional dog name.

history.modern_era: Cerberus remains one of the most recognizable figures from Greek mythology. The term 'Cerberus' is used metaphorically for any fierce guardian or insurmountable obstacle. The creature appears throughout literature, from Dante to Harry Potter, and in countless games, films, and works of art.

hercules_labor.title: The Twelfth Labor of Hercules
hercules_labor.summary: As his twelfth and final labor, Hercules was commanded to capture Cerberus and bring him to King Eurystheus. Hercules descended to the underworld and asked Hades for permission. Hades agreed if Hercules could subdue Cerberus without weapons. Hercules wrestled the beast with his bare hands until Cerberus submitted. He brought Cerberus to the surface, terrifying Eurystheus, then returned him to the underworld.

orpheus_myth.title: Orpheus and Eurydice
orpheus_myth.summary: When Orpheus descended to the underworld to retrieve his dead wife Eurydice, he charmed Cerberus to sleep with his lyre music. The beautiful music allowed Orpheus to pass the guardian without conflict.

aeneas_sibyl.title: Aeneas and the Sibyl
aeneas_sibyl.summary: In Virgil's Aeneid, the Sibyl helps Aeneas enter the underworld by drugging Cerberus with honey cakes laced with soporifics, allowing peaceful passage.
